INTRODUCTION 1.1 The Government of Mali has requested IDA assistance in financing a project to improve the quality, supply and relevance of its vocational education and training (VET) services, in order to increase the responsiveness of such services to labor market demand for skilled workers. This increased coherence between training and emplovment is a key factor for achieving Mali's overall development objectives of growth and poverty reduction, and is an essential aspect of human resources development, a cornerstone of IDA's Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Mali. 1.2 The project would improve the quality, supply and relevance of VET services through consolidation of pre-service VET training streams, and creation of a Vocational Training Support Fund for in-service skills upgrading. In addition, the project would improve labor market information analysis and dissemination through the establishment of an Employment and Training Observatory at the National Manpower and Employment Office. 1.3 Project investments would include hardware and software investments in both pre-service and in- service VET to improve training capacity and quality. This would include civil works, equipment, pedagogical materials, training of trainers, teacher upgrading, curriculum and examination reforms, and institutional capacity-building. A revision of all legal texts pertaining to VET would be completed before project effectiveness, in order to improve Government's capacity to allocate training resources as a function of labor market demand, and to increase the involvement of the private sector in the management, provision and financing of VET. The total project would cost US$ 22.9 million (including taxes and duties), with a foreign exchange component of US$ 14.8 million. Of this, Government and employers would contribute US$ 5.8 rmillion, IDA wvould finance US$ 13.4 million, and the Fonds dAide et de Cooperation (FAC) would provide US$ 3.7 million. 1.4 This project was prepared in-country, with the task manager located in the Resident Mission. This enabled extensive beneficiary participation, near exclusive use of national consultants for preparatory studies, and close collaboration with Government officials and other donors. In addition to a three-person Government preparation team, a "consultative group" for the project was established, including the National Federation of Malian Employers, the National Federation of Malian Artisans, NGOs, women's associations, private training centers, and recent school graduates. Weekly meetings with the task manager during preparation resulted in firm ownership and commitment to the project among the Borrower and intended project beneficiaries. In particular, the Operations Manual for the proposed Vocational Training Support Fund was drafted, revised and finalized in concert with the consultative group. A Japanese PHRD Grant for US$300,000 and a Project Preparation Facility for US$ 350,000 financed the necessary consultants and other project preparation activities.
 2 A. MACROECONOMY AND EMPLOYMENT Macroeconomy 1.5 Mali is a vast, landlocked and resource-poor country located in the Sahelian zone of westem Africa. About 75 percent of the population, estimated at about 9 million in 1995, is engaged in the agricultural sector, which accounts for approximately 50 percent of GDP. Per capita income is estimated at just US$250 (1994) and social indicators (such as life expectancy, literacy and infant mortality) are among the lowest in the world (Mali ranked 167 out of 173 countries in the UNDP rating of human resources development in 1994). 1.6 Mali's potential for long-term growth is subject to harsh resource constraints. Growth in the agricultural sector is largely conditioned bv variable rainfall, fragile soils and low-productivity traditional technologies. Secondly, extremely low literacy and schooling rates, and scarce technical skills, pose additional obstacles to agricultural and industrial development. These problems are compounded bv high population growth (2.7%), which puts severe pressure on both the limited natural resource base and the resources available for basic public services (such as education) and other productive investments, in tum restricting employment opportunities. 1.7 On the bright side, real GDP grew an average of 3.1% annuallv between 1992-1994 (following stagnant GDP growth between 1980 and 1991), and the devaluation of the West African Franc (CFAF) in early 1994 offers the country the possibility to exploit its comparative advantages in agriculture, agro- processing, and production of low-technology import substitutes, thereby increasing incomes for both rural and urban populations. Furthermore. recent macroeconomic management has been largely positive, with all macroeconomic objectives achieved in 1994 and 1995. Inflation has been contained, exports have increased significantly, and fiscal and current account deficits in 1994 were lower than projected. Private capital reflows have picked up and private consumption is shifting to local products. The three-year public investment program for 1995-1997 is being satisfactorily implemented, and real GDP is expected to grow at an average annual rate of 5.0% between 1995 and 1997. The overall picture which emerges is one of opportunity, which must be supported by investments to generate the needed supply response, particularly in the area of human resources. Labor Force and Employment 1.8 Supply. Mali has one of the least-skilled labor forces in the world. The vast majoritv of the active labor force has had no schooling whatsoever, the adult literacy rate is estimated at 20%, and the mean years of schooling for adults aged 25 years or more is just 0.3 years. The gross primary enrollment rate is 35% (1995), and only 25% for girls. (For more complete statistics on school enrollments, see Annex 4.1). Development of primarv education is therefore the first priority for improving the quality of Mali's labor force (which will be supported with IDA financing through a recently-identified Education Sector Investment Program). Beyond primarv education, the labor force needs basic professional and technical skills - literacy and numeracy alone are not enough. 1.9 The active labor force is estimated at 3.6 million workers (45% of the population is under 15). The agriculture sector absorbs the greatest proportion of labor (about 75%), but this sector is characterized by significant underemployment, often leading to urban migration. Manufacturing, construction and artisanal occupations represent about 10% of the labor force, with the services sector accounting for another 15%.
 3 1.10 The modem sector is estimated at 14.000 private sector workers, 11,000 parastatal employees and 37,000 civil servants. The Government's reform program has resulted in a near-freeze on hiring in the public sector, voluntary civil servant departures and public enterprise lay-offs. Under the most optimistic assumptions, growth over the short-term of formal private and public sector employment (currently around 1,300 jobs per year) will be unable to absorb the stock of already unemployed and the annual inflow of 80,000 newcomers into the labor market. Due to the momentum of population growth, this annual inflow into the labor market will rise to 110,000 by 2005 and 140,000 by 2015. 1.11 The informal sector of the economy is, and will remain for the near future, the primary source of non-agricultural employment. Of the non-agricultural labor force, approximately 90% (or 700,000 workers) are in the informal sector. With limited capital, the informal sector relies on high-intensity, low- skill, low-cost labor, which obevs a mix of competitive market laws and tradition. Hiring, pay and dismissals are flexible and determined bv market considerations (supply and demand for specific skills as derived from goods markets), and familv/ethnic relations. 1.12 Between 1976 and 1988 registered. open unemployment doubled, and since then has remained at the current level of around 20%. Youth unemployment (ages 15-29) makes up about two-thirds of open unemployment, and 85% of registered jobseekers are young. The primary causes of this unemployment are slow economic growth and general job scarcity. worsened by training programs which are poorly adapted to labor market demand. Migration remains a popular response - approximately I million Malians work abroad, although job opportunities in destination countries have declined. 1.13 Demand. A series of 7 labor market and training surveys were conducted during project preparation to ascertain labor market demand (in both formal and informal sectors, in Bamako and in the regions), and to identifv vocational training streams most likely to lead to employment. A synthesis of these studies indicates important labor market growth opportunities in certain sectors after the CFAF devaluation, increasing demand for skilled manpower, and heightened employer concern over the quality of trained staff available. (These studies included: a tracer study of recent VET graduates, a studv of private sector training needs in Bamako, an analysis of the apprenticeship/production system in the informal sector, A survey of economic growth and employment trends in the regions. an analysis of data from the Annual Manpower Survey for the years 1988-1993; a reverse tracer study of recent VET graduates; and a study of women's constraints to training and their training needs. For more information see Annex 2.2). 1.14 More specifically, significant growsth in production and employment are expected over the medium term in the following areas: basic industries (principally textiles, agro-industrv and simple import substitution), construction, public works, transport, hotels and tourism, crafts, and small and medium enterprises. (Note that similar conclusions regarding promising economic sub-sectors were reached in the World Bank's 1994 Private Sector Assessment for Mali.) This will require technically qualified specialists in maintenance, mechanics (general, auto and truck). metalwork, electricity, construction and accounting. Mid-level skilled workers will be most in demand (i.e. people willing and able to perform skilled tasks themselves and, if necessary, to supervise others). Geographic centers for employment growth include Bamako and the regional capitals of Sikasso, Segou and Kayes. These regional capitals correspond, respectively, to the cotton, rice and mining production areas, which are developing rapidly following the 1994 CFAF devaluation. Currently, mid-level technical skills are often imported to meet this demand from Senegal, Togo, Ivorv Coast, even the Philippines (for example, for construction of the Selingue Dam and the West African Central Bank, routine mechanical repair jobs in industry, and development of the mining sector).
 4 1.15 Labor Market Policy. As part of the World Bank-financed Structural Adjustment Program, the Mali Labor Code was substantially revised in 1992, liberalizing important aspects of the code pertaining to employee hiring and dismissal, the role of the National Manpower and Employment Office, and leave policies (see Annex 5. 1). However, the legal texts required to apply the revised Labor Code were never approved by the Government, due to opposition from national unions. As part of the 1995-1997 Policy Framnework Paper signed with the Bretton Woods Institutions, the Government has agreed to review the implementation of the revised code with the aim of identifying further areas of reform to allow more flexibility in the functioning of the labor market. Following this, the legal framework of the revised Labor Code will be strengthened to ensure full application. B. THE BANK'S COUNTRY ASSISTANCE STRATEGY 1.16 The goal of the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy for Mali is the alleviation of poverty through a 3-pronged approach: (i) sustained broad-based economic growth, (ii) human resources development, and (iii) a special focus on the needs of the most vulnerable. Sound macroeconomic management and local institutional capacity-building are essential to achieving these goals. In operational terms, this strategy requires lending in education, training, health, agriculture, infrastructure, and urban job creation. The proposed VET project responds to all three aspects of the Bank's strategy - by developing skills which correspond to new employment opportunities, particularly among individuals in the informal sector and/or outside of the formal education system, the Bank would contribute to economic growth, human resources development and target the needs of relatively disadvantaged groups in urban areas.
 2. VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING A. VET SERVICES Pre-Service VET 2.1 Structure and Administration. Mali currently offers three pre-service VET programs to prepare youth for entry into the labor market, all at the upper secondary level (10th grade): (a) 2-year VET offering the Certificat d'Aptitude Professionnel (CAP) in 13 specialties; (b) 3-year technical training leading to the Baccalaureat Technique (BTN) in three specialties; and (c) four-year VET training for the Brevet Technicien (BT) in 20 specialties. In 1995 the CAP was offered to 7,680 students, 30% of whom attend the Vocational Training School (CFP) in Bamako, with the rest enrolled in 5 small regional vocational training institutes (IFPs) and 13 private schools (which receive public subsidies on a per student basis). The BTN was provided to 1,430 students at the Lycee Technique, while the BT was offered to 3,000 students at ECICA (Ecole d'Industrie, Commerce et Administration), plus another 1,300 students spread out in the IFPs and 9 private training centers. Overall, the VET system enrolled 16,950 students in 1995, while output has averaged 2,300 graduates per year. Public pre-service VET services are administered by the Department of Technical Education and Vocational Training (DNETP) within the Ministry of Secondary and Higher Education and Scientific Research, while private schools are independently managed. These training institutes are not considered under this project, because of the focus on training for
 6 the private sector, particularly in industrial skills and the informal sector, as opposed to training for government emplovees. 2.3 Formal pre-service apprenticeship training as part of VET does not exist in Mali, although an embryonic apprenticeship progran for recent graduates is developing. Under this program the employer agrees to hire the apprentice for a period of six months at 50% of normal wages, in return for which the employer can deduct from taxable income what is paid in wages. However, early results from this program are not encouraging, as few employers find the fiscal incentives sufficient and prefer to arrange informal apprenticeship training without government intervention. 2.4 Financing of pre-service VET. In 1995 Government recurrent expenditures on pre-service VET were estimated at 10% of total education expenditures, an increase from an average of 7% of total education expenditures between 1987-1992 (compared to 14% for general secondarv). 47% of public VET financing went to private VET providers in 1995, based on per student subsidies for teaching personnel and educational materials. Annual per student costs for pre-service VET were an estimated US$325 in 1994, varying by stream from US$170 for administration/finance to US$220 for accounting, US$450 for auto mechanics. and US$600 for civil works. Cost recovery is not practiced. About 50% of VET expenditures goes to personnel, 35% for equipment, materials, and maintenance. and 15% for student scholarships. There has been no significant investment financing since the 1970s. except for minor foreign assistance in auto mechanics, air conditioning and electricity in the mid-1980s. In-Service VET Apprenticeship Training 2.5 Traditional apprenticeship training has a long historv in Mali, and consists of learning practical skills from a master artisan in more than 70 professional trades in the informal sector, including construction, metalwork, auto mechanics, woodworking, dressmaking, soapmaking, food preparation, jeatherwork, hairdressing and artwork. It has both economic and social rationales: the apprentice provides cheap labor in exchange for learning practical skills, and in the process acquires traditional values of solidanrty and respect for one's elders, which are essential to Mali's social fabric. An estimated 45,000 apprentices work and train in Bamako alone, and outside the capital this is the only form of non-tertiary vocational training available. Apprenticeship training is thus more important than formal pre-service VET, in terms of numbers of trainees and preparation of youth for immediate entry into the labor market. 2.6 Training is a bv-product of production, not an activity undertaken for its own sake in preparation for a job. Typicallv. one craftsman employs 4-5 apprentices, who varv in seniority and sophistication of tasks assigned. Apprentices may spend the first year simply cleaning the workshop, observing others and preparing tea. Practical tasks are assigned once the apprentice has demonstrated obedience and respect. Depending on the trade, training lasts from I -10 years, although the average is 3-5 years. The long apprenticeship period, the market requirement that the work performed be worthy of sale, and the emphasis on practical skills means that trainees are often more skilled in their trade than their counterparts who attended formal pre-service VET. 2.7 Apprenticeship training is not structured nor effectively regulated. In most cases, masters pay apprentices a subsistence wage (US$1- 1.25 per day), although sometimes parents pay a token amount to the master, or the exchange of labor for training is simply bartered. But changes in economic and social
 7 realities are changing apprenticeship training, as well. The demand for training is increasing (due to demographic growth, rural to urban migration, and the stagnation of the education svstem and civil service), the number of trades is increasing with modernization, and the reservation of specific trades to certain ethnic groups is disappearing. The level of schooling before apprenticeship is also increasing: 68% of apprentices surveved in 1994 were literate, whereas 10 years ago apprentices typically had no schooling whatsoever. This means that apprentices are increasingly able to read diagrams and learn theoretical principles to support their practical training, although few master artisans are able to provide this kind of instruction (60% of artisans never attended primary school). Skills Upgrading 2.8 24 public and 13 private skills upgrading centers exist, almost all in Bamako. Public centers are associated with specific ministries and train mainly civil servants and parastatal employees, while private centers offer training in management, computing and office skills, but rarely technical/industrial skills. To finance skills upgrading and employment services for formal private and parastatal enterprises, employers pay an "employment services tax", equal to 1% of the payroll, which generates about 450 million CFAF per year (roughly 20% of public pre-service VET expenditures). In practice, however, this money is simply allocated to the National Employment and Manpower Office (ONMOE) and used for financing of administrative costs. job placement, labor market surveys, and the operation of a small secretarial and accounting training center used primarily by public and parastatal sector workers. 2.9 In the informal sector. considerable skills upgrading goes on, although this is difficult to distinguish from the informal apprenticeship system. The more successful master artisans may have three classes of workers under them: full-time skilled workers who perform a wide range of tasks, third- or fourth-year apprentices who perform a limited range of tasks, and newly-recruited apprentices who are confined to observing, cleaning and other non-skilled activities. Many artisans now belong to craft guilds, which offer limited training in both technical and managerial aspects of their businesses to regular employees. Lastly, Mali's NGOs provide significant skills upgrading opportunities in management, accounting, project feasibilitv analvsis, etc., but very little in terms of industrial/technical skills. B. CONSTRAINTS TO DEVELOPMENT OF VET SERVICES Constraints to Pre-Service VET 2.10 Summary: The pre-service VET training system, designed to prepare youth for entry into the labor market, is poorly adapted to labor market demand, of low quality, inefficient, inequitable. inappropriatelv administered, inadequately financed, lacking in diversity and flexibility, and insufficiently informed. However, this is due primarily to neglect - the system retains considerable potential to contribute to Mali's economic development, provided that appropriate reforms and investments are carried out. 2.11 Pre-service VET is poorly adapted to labor market demand, mainly because it has been driven bv the logic of student flow management, a response to the Government's obligation to enroll all graduates from basic education at the secondary level. [Note: a new policy of access to secondary education, based on academic performance and enrollment capacity, is being implemented as of school year 1995/96, under the Mali Education Sector Adjustment Loan.] That is, the gradual expansion of basic education has resulted in more graduates than public secondary and higher education institutions can accommodate, which has led the Government to orient "surplus" students to private, tertiary VET institutions, which receive public subsidies on a per student basis. While a good idea in principle, these private schools offer almost
 8 exclusively tertiary sector training (because it is cheaper), and systematically overstate their capacity in order to receive as many students as possible, which results in serious overcrowding and poor instruction. Tertiary VET (which enrolls 75% of all VET students) has become a kind of "release valve" to move students out of the education system, and produces graduates with skills for which the labor market is largely saturated. Meanwhile, labor market studies show increasing demand for skilled mechanics, metalworkers, electricians, builders and accountants, but current capacity allows just 25% of VET students to pursue industrial/technical training. Furthermore, the programs which exist are too theoretical and designed to produce supervisors and foremen, not skilled workers. In fact, many employers are reluctant to hire VET graduates who believe they are "above" performing skilled manual labor. 2.12 The quality of pre-service VET is very low, whether assessed in terms of equipment, instruction, curricula, examinations or employer opinions. Particularly at the CAP level, training facilities are obsolete (the Vocational Training Center was last equipped by the Soviets in 1962), while minimal operations and maintenance budgets cannot maintain what little remains. Most buildings are old and in need of repair and renovation to protect equipment from theft and weather. The quality of instruction is poor: 40% of VET instructors are uncertified contractors, most of whom are recent graduates of BT and CAP programs, with little practical experience in the private sector. There are few qualified trainers and inspectors. The content and duration of VET programs are rigid, reflecting educational goals and academic concerns rather than labor market skills requirements. Examinations are mainly theoretical and academic, rather than assessments of practical competencies. The average repetition rate among CAP students is 30%, and failure rates on the CAP exam average 65%. Most importantly, poor quality is revealed in the opinions of modem sector employers, many of whom express dissatisfaction with pre-service VET trainees and consequent reluctance to employ them. The low quality of VET thus defeats its purpose. 2.13 Pre-Service VET services are inefficient and inequitable. Teaching workloads are low: the full- time load is just 18 hours per week, but the average instructor works only 14 hours per week. The average student:teacher ratio is 14: 1, but this varies from 3:1 to 23: 1, depending on the institution and training stream. Girls are underrepresented, accounting for only 26% of VET enrollments, in part due to extremely low girls' enrollment rates at the basic education level (about one-third of primary enrollnent). 83% of girls are enrolled in tertiary sector training (secretarial skills, accounting, office/administration skills, etc.). Finally, access to VET is geographicallv inequitable - with 90% of all training places in Bamako, youth outside the capital have verv limited access to VET services, even though 40% of the formal labor market and most of the informal labor market is outside the capital. 2.14 Management of VET is inflexible and inadequate. Insufficient leeway is accorded to school directors to administer, recruit trainers and students, mobilize resources, and adapt curricula. There is little or no participation by employers, artisans or the ONMOE in curriculum design, student orientation, financing or practical training activities. At the central level, institutional capacity of the DNETP is weak, with few qualified staff and inadequate resources to efficientlv allocate student places, teachers, materials, etc., and monitor their utilization. 2.15 VET is underfunded and its financing is mismanaged. Not enough resources are allocated to materials and maintenance expenditures, while too much is spent on student scholarships and other subsidies (uniforms, notebooks, etc.). Investment financing is negligible, and cost recoverv in the public system is not practiced. Almost 3/4 of public VET expenditures go to tertiary training, although the demand in the labor market is primarily for industrial training. The informal sector receives no public financing whatsoever, although it trains three times as many youth as the formal system. (Additional details on sector financing, budgetarv allocations and actual VET expenditures are provided in Annex 4.1)
 9 2.16 Inadequate labor market information limits the ability to adapt VET services to labor market demand. Labor market statistics are only collected in the modem sector, providing an inadequate basis for analyses of employment trends, earnings, labor mobility and detection of skills shortages. At the ONMOE, job vacancy data is sporadically collected, employer surveys are rarely conducted, job counseling is minimal, placement services are slow and unreliable, and few enterprises inform the ONMOE of manpower needs. Coordination with other agencies collecting labor market information is poor. Beyond collection of labor market information, there is little analvsis and dissemination of information for policvmakers, training institutions, and the public at large (especiallv parents and students), which means labor market information is not used for VET planning and resource allocation. Constraints to In-Service VET Apprenliceship Training 2.17 Non-fornal apprenticeship training suffers from pedagogic, economic and social constraints, each of which is discussed below. 2.18 Pedagogic: Apprentices learn through observation, imitation, and trial and error. While effective in developing practical skills, such training offers few opportunities to learn the basic principles and theory behind the practical skills. Secondly, innovation and the acquisition of new technologies are not favored by simple repetition of tasks - current apprenticeship training locks the informal sector in a low-technology loop. Thirdly, there is no logical sequence or structure to the training and skills acquired, no conmnon set of standards for each trade, nor any certification procedure (an important labor market signal), so trained apprentices have difficulty establishing themselves on their own. Finally, training is almost exclusively in national languages and most master artisans are illiterate, which means little use of instruction manuals, blueprints or other written materials, even though almost 70% of apprentices surveyed in 1994 stated they were literate and numerate. This limnits the extent of instruction and lengthens the training period. 2.19 Economic: In the informal sector, the daily struggle is simply to survive - the evening's meal is often paid for from the receipts of the day. This means few resources are available for training per se. Because apprenticeship training is a by-product of production, it is a function of the contracts gained by the master artisan. The more orders placed and the greater their diversity, the faster and broader is the training acquired by apprentices; on the other hand, during slow periods apprentices may learn nothing at all. Thirdly, because of limited client purchasing power, demand is often for final products of very low quality, which restricts the skills apprentices can acquire. Finally, the master artisan must guard against future competition, and so may withhold certain trade secrets to prevent the apprentice from setting up his or her own business. 2.20 Social: Apprenticeship training depends on the personal relationship between the master artisan and the apprentice (and often the apprentice's family). It is unregulated, with no written contracts. The process is long, on average about 5 years, but lasting up to 10 years. Apprenticeship typically ends when the master decides the apprentice has learned all the master can teach. Because the master artisan has an interest in retaining the apprentice's cheap, skilled labor (and preventing competition), this decision is often delayed - the apprentice must defer to his elders and can be locked into a form of social bondage. Secondly, apprenticeship training is not valued by society as a whole. While within the trade it has a time-honored place and is essential for the trade's continuity, it is often described as the "wastebasket" for youth outside the formal education system (which offers diplomas and social status). Until recently, governnent cadres (most of wvhom have formal education degrees and middle class status) showed little interest in supporting
 10 apprenticeship training with public resources. This results in a vicious circle of poor training quality, weak trainee marketability, and low status of apprenticeship training. Skills Upgrading 2.21 Skills upgrading services are simnply inadequate, both quantitatively and qualitatively. Employers in the formal and nonformal private sectors invest little in skills upgrading, in part because many of them function on the edge of bankruptcy and cannot afford to invest for medium-term pay-offs. In addition, because the modem sector and the average size of firmns are small, there is little demand to develop enterprise-based training capacity. Poorly organized trade associations are another inhibiting factor, as is Mali's history of state domination of the means of production. Although the Governent maintains skills upgrading centers for public employees in civil works, electricity, transport, textiles and construction, these facilities have not been available to the private sector. From the employee perspective, there is little incentive to invest in skills upgrading which does not lead to a government-sanctioned diploma, because the administered wage system in the modern sector is based on diplomas and seniority, not on productivity, and because promotions are often based on family and social relations. 2.22 While recent surveys suggest that private sector employers consider product quality and productivitv as the key factors in their competitiveness in national and regional markets, few employers make the link between these factors and skills development. Those that do cite the poor quality of existing training services in Mali and the excessively high costs of sending workers abroad as constraints to investments in skills upgrading. On the other hand, they indicate a willingness to pay for quality, local training adapted to their specific needs. 2.23 Women's access to skills upgrading opportunities is particularly restricted. Not only are they subject to the same constraints as men (e.g. the cost of training, distance to training sites, lack of employer concern, etc.), but they also must overcome additional constraints related to their domestic responsibilities. Simply put, working women have less disposable time in Mali than most men, because they must also take care of the children, cook, clean, wash, fetch water, etc.. In a recently conducted survey, many women also complained of reluctance on their husbands' part to let them participate in training activities, much less use household money to pay for such training. Finally, these additional constraints to training should be viewed in light of women's relatively greater training needs: working women's literacy, numeracy, technical and managerial skills are far below those of their male counterparts. The Bank's expenrence suggests numerous lessons to be incorporated in the Bank's education and training strategy for Mali. (i) Quality pnrmary and lower secondary education are critical to success in vocational training programs. This lesson is reflected through IDA's IV Education Project, the Education SECAL, and the recently-identified Education Sector Investment Program. (ii) Public pre-service training in secondary vocational schools may be justified when employer and private training capacity is weak, but these programs require sufficient recurrent cost funding and a strong market orientation in planning and institutional responsiveness. For example, the PCR of the Mali First Education Project found the VET component particularly successful and stated that additional IDA inputs would have been helpful, especially if employers contributed more to the design of practical training programs, and adequate public funds were budgeted for ECICA's operational costs. During preparation of the proposed VET project, emplovers were involved in both research and project design, and seven labor market studies were undertaken to ensure VET/market orientation. Under the project, recurrent cost funding norms would be increased, emplovers would be included in both pre- and in-service VET management, and labor market studies would be continued through the Employment and Training Observatory. (iii) Practical apprenticeship programs mav be cost-effective complements to theoretical training. (v) Diversification of financing is important for both sustainability and equity in sharing of costs and benefits. Under the project, the introduction of a Vocational Training Tax (equivalent to 0.5% of the private and parastatal payroll), plus the 25% counterpart contribution for all VTSF-financed training (paid by the trainees, their employers or their sponsors), would ensure sustainability and introduce VET cost recovery for the first time in Mali. This analysis included 8 dimensions: (a) the placement of the project in the larger macro-economic context, considering the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy for Mali and future growth trends: (b) qualitative and quantitative results from employer and manpower surveys; (c) calculations of the rate of return to vocational education and training services, based on unit costs, wages and probability of employment by training stream, and sensitivity analyses of these rate of return calculations to determine key variables for scrutiny during implementation; (d) the development of a least-cost alternative for VET investments; (e) fiscal impact analysis, which examines the recurrent cost impact of proposed project investments and compares this to current spending levels, and addresses cost-recovery issues; (f) institutional analysis, which assesses the capacity of the National Department for Technical and Vocational Training, the Vocational Training Support Fund and the Employment and Training Observatory to implement this project; (g) poverty analysis, which specifies which benefits would go to the poor and examines the project's impact on beneficiaries' incomes; and finally (h) the identification of economic performance indicators for monitoring and feedback during implementation (for indicators see Annex 6.4). Viewed together, the economic analysis of the Mali VET Consolidation Project permits a positive overall assessment and argues for the project's financing. 5.2 As mentioned in Chapter 1, Mali's macroeconomic performance and expected growth augur well for the project, which is fully consistent with the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy. Labor market demand for technical and vocational skills (also discussed in Chapter 1) is expected to grow principally in textiles, agro-industry, simple import substitution, construction, public works, transport, hotels and tourism, crafts, and small and medium enterprises. Similar conclusions regarding promising economic sub- sectors were reached in the World Bank's 1994 Private Sector Assessment for Mali. This will require technically qualified specialists in maintenance, mechanics (general, auto and truck), metalwork, electricity, construction and accounting/management. 5.3 Economic rates of return (both private and social) to 2- and 4-year vocational education and training were calculated, overall and by training stream. (Note: the economic rate of return is the rate of interest that equates the discounted present value of expected benefits and the present value of costs. The private rate of return measures the relationship between the costs and benefits of education for the individual, and the social rate of return measures the relationship between all the social costs of training that must be bome by society as a whole, and the benefits that are expected to accrue to society.) These rates are relative to 9 years of basic education leading to the Basic Education Diploma (the prerequisite for entry into formal VET training institutions), and were calculated using data from the Annual Manpower Surveys regarding salaries by education and training levels, unit cost information by training stream, and hypotheses with respect to the probability of VET trainees obtaining jobs in their field, derived in part from the VET tracer study discussed above. For 2-year VET, the private and social rates of return are estimated at 27% and 13%, respectively. For 4-year VET, the private and social rates of return are estimated at 33% and 21%, respectively. Note that these calculations are based on wages in the modern sector and so may overestimate average trainee eamings. On the other hand, quite conservative estimates were used with respect to the probability of employment (a maximum of 75% three years after graduation), and extemal
 33 benefits to training such as technological innovations, social cohesion, better health, reduced fertility, intergenerational benefits, etc. were not calculated into the social rate of retum. 5.4 Sensitivity analysis suggests that to achieve at least a 10% social rate of return among CAP trainees overall, at least 70% need to find ajob within three years of graduation, which pays at least 60,000 FCFA per month (about US$110). For BT trainees overall, at least 75% need to be employed within three years of graduation, and eaming at least 90,000 FCFA per month (about US$180). (See Annex 2.1 for sensitivity analyses of individual training streams.) This seems quite plausible given current employment and salary trends. For example, in 1993, average monthly eamings for CAP-level modem sector workers were CFAF 61,475, while those for BT-level employees were CFAF 114,500 (see Annex 2.2 for trends in monthly salaries by economic sector and training level). These average salary levels have increased an estimated 15% since the devaluation of the CFAF in 1994. 5.5 For in-service training, a rate of return was calculated using estimates of unit costs and of trainee salaries before and after training. Assuming a unit cost of US$ 140 per month of training (the figure used in the Project Cost Tables), a US$ 10 increase in monthly earnings 12 months after training, and a slight increase in the probability of being employed after training, the social rate of return to VTSF training activities would be 34%. To achieve a minimum 10% rate of retum, trainees would have to be at least as likely to be employed after the training as before, and would have to be eaming at least US$ 7 more per month after the training. Assuming the training financed meets certain economic, financial and pedagogic criteria, this minimum rate of return appears likely to be achieved. 5.6 A least-cost altemative approach was used during project appraisal, which attempted to reduce VET unit costs through the design of multi-use, full-time training facilities which can be shared between CAP and BT training institutions. An in-depth needs assessment, based on an extensive inventory of existing training equipment, coupled with continued labor market demand and training supply analysis, ensured that the project would only finance essential training equipment. The result of this approach was to reduce final estimates for civil works and equipment required for consolidating pre-service VET services from US$ 6.2 million (pre-appraisal) to US$ 3.8 million (appraisal). 5.7 Additional recurrent costs linked to investments in pre-service VET are estimated in nominal tenns at CFAF 150 million, beginning in 1998, primarily for equipment maintenance, repairs and raw materials. Relative to 1995 expenditures, this would be equivalent to an increase in real terms of 9% for pre-service VET materials, of 4% in total VET expenditures, or 0.5% in total education spending. During negotiations Government provided assurance that as of 1998 it would increase educational materials financing to CFAF 60, 000 per VET student, and maintain this as a minimum for the duration ofproject implementation (para 7. 1-h); this increase should be covered primarily by reducing scholarship expenditures, although some additional resources may be required. Total VET unit costs (both investment and recurrent) would increase to about US$750 per year, equivalent to approxinately two times general secondary unit costs. This 2:1 ratio of VET to general secondary unit costs conforms to international norms and reflects the added costs for equipment, materials, practical training and smaller classes. 5.8 For the first time in Mali, employer contributions and beneficiary cost recovery for in-service VET services would be institutionalized. Employers would contribute approximately CFAF 300 million per year to the Vocational Training Support Fund, through the 0.5% payroll tax for vocational training, Training beneficiaries (or their employers or sponsors) would also pay 25% of the cost of VTSF-financed training (10% for young apprentices). As for pre-service VET, while the economic rationale for increased cost- recovery is apparent, this issue needs to be addressed for the sector as a whole, particularly at the higher education level, before it can be introduced in the context of this project (the recently-identified Education

Under the project, through the Vocational Training Support Fund, approximately 8,000 workers and apprentices would benefit from one month of in-service training each year for five years, with relatively poor informal sector workers and apprentices constituting approximately 50% of all beneficiaries. In other words, the project would provide approximately 20,000 poor workers with skills upgrading. These workers should demonstrate improved vocational and entrepreneurial skills, thereby improving productivity, labor mobility, employment prospects, and earnings. 5.10 Women, in particular, have very low levels of literacy, basic education and training, and very little access to training opportunities. On the other hand, they represent a large share of workers in the informal sector, engaged in agro-processing, dressmaking, soapmaking, dyeing, commerce, and other trades. The proposed project would reach out and support the training of female workers in small and micro- enterprises, in both formal and informal sectors, and would provide women with greater opportunities to enhance their skills, productivity and earnings. VET trainees should demonstrate improved vocational and entrepreneurial skills, thereby improving productivity, labor mobility, employment prospects, and economic growth. PROJECT RISKS 6.2 The greatest risk to this project is the possibility that growth of the economy and of labor market demand for the skills to be developed under the project will be insufficient. While current economic indicators provide grounds for optimism, Mali's economy is extremely vulnerable to changes in climate and externally-defined commodity prices. Quite frankly, there is little the proposed project can do to minimize this risk, except to diversify training activities to cover a range of economic sectors - slow growth in one sector may be offset by rapid growth in another, and so overall project performance would be satisfactory. The second risk is political and social pressure arising from increased numbers of basic education graduates, which hinders the control of VET enrollment growth and the Government's ability to reduce and/or phase out training streams no longer demanded in the labor market. This is being addressed through: revised, transparent admissions policies being applied for the school year 1995-1996; a clear definition of what constitutes VET's enrollment capacity; and the Government's ongoing public communications program linked to execution of the Education SECAL. The third risk is resistance within the MESSRS to execute curricula reforms, and to involve employers in VET management. This is being addressed by an ongoing, participatory training program for VET administrators and teachers which covers labor market demand, curriculum requirements, teacher training, and school management. The fourth risk is weak implementation capacity and delays in project start-up, which are being addressed through a Project Preparation Facility to finance the recruitment and training of project staff, the installation and training for both financial and project implementation monitoring systems, the pilot testing of a range of training sub-projects under the VTSF, the development of in-service training curricula, promotional activities to inform targeted groups about the project, advance preparation of procurement documents and a project launch seminar. Finallv, employers may not be willing to play an active role in managing either pre-service or in-service VET. This risk has been minimized through private sector involvement in the preparation and design of this project, in particular with respect to the Vocational Training Support Fund (the private sector would assume the presidency of the VTSF Management Committee). 6.3 Environment. Viewed together, the economic analysis of the Mali VET Consolidation Project permits a positive overall assessment and argues for the project's financing. A. Macroeconomic Context and the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy for Mali Mali is a vast, landlocked and resource-poor country located in the Sahelian zone of western Africa. Per capita income is estimated at just US$250 (1994) and social indicators (such as life expectancy, literacy and infant mortality) are among the lowest in the world. More than 75 percent of the population, estimated at about 9 million in 1995, is engaged in the agricultural sector, which accounts for approximately 50 percent of GDP. Growth in this sector is conditioned by variable rainfall, fragile soils and low- productivity traditional technologies. The weak human resource base and scarcity of technical skills pose a formidable obstacle to both agricultural and industrial development. These problems are compounded by high population growth (2.7%) which puts severe pressure on both the limited natural resource base and the financial resources available for basic public services and productive investments, which in turn restricts employment opportunities.
 Annex 2.1 page 2 of 10 On the bright side, real GDP grew an average of 3.1% annually between 1992- 1994 (following stagnant GDP growth between 1980 and 1991), and the devaluation of the West African Franc (CFAF) in early 1994 offers the country the possibility to exploit its comparative advantages in agriculture, agro-processing, and production of low- technology import substitutes, thereby increasing employment and incomes for both rural and urban populations. Furthermore, recent macroeconomic management has been largely positive, with all macroeconomic objectives achieved in 1994 and through June 1995. Inflation has been contained, exports have increased significantly, and fiscal and current account deficits in 1994 were lower than programmed. Private capital reflows have picked up and private consumption is shifting to local products. The three-year public investment program for 1994-1996 is being satisfactorily implemented, and real GDP is expected to grow at an average annual rate of 5.0% between 1995 and 1997. The overall picture which emerges is one of opportunity, which must be supported by investments to generate the needed supply response, particularly in the area of human resources. The Mali VET Consolidation Project represents an example of such investments. The goal of the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy for Mali is the alleviation of poverty through a 3-pronged approach: (i) sustained broad-based economic growth, (ii) human resources development and (iii) a special focus on the needs of the most vulnerable. Sound macroeconomic management and local institutional capacity-building are essential to achieving these goals. In operational terms, this strategy requires investment and adjustment lending in education, training, health, agriculture, infrastructure, and urban job creation. The proposed vocational education and training project responds to all three aspects of the Bank's strategy: by developing skills which correspond to new employmnent opportunities, particularly among individuals working in the informal sector, the Bank would contribute to economic growth, human resources development and target the needs of relatively disadvantaged groups in urban areas.  Annex 2.1 page 10 of 10 G. Poverty Analysis The Mali VET Consolidation Project would primarily address skill defiiciencies among urban workers, a large proportion of whom are poor. In general, the urban poor have very little general or vocational education and training. This, in turn, limits their access to employment and revenue-generating activities. Under the project, through the Vocational Training Support Fund, approximately 8,000 workers and apprentices would benefit from one month of in-service training each year for five years, with relatively poor informal sector workers and apprentices constituting approximately 50% of all beneficiaries. In other words, the project would provide approximately 20,000 poor workers with skills upgrading. These workers should demonstrate improved vocational and entrepreneurial skills, thereby improving productivity, labor mobility, employment prospects, and earnings. Among students reaching upper secondary education, those oriented to pre-service VET training demonstrate lower academic achievement at the basic education level than those oriented to general secondary. Such lower achievement is positively correlated in Mali with socio-economic status, meaning that pre-service VET students, in general, come from poorer households than students oriented to general secondary. In addition, many students now request to be oriented to pre-service VET training, rather than to general secondary. Typically, these students come from households which cannot afford the opportunity costs of education through the highest levels, and so they choose training which can enable them to find a job as quickly as possible. Under the project, 1,120 students per year (for approximately fifteen years) would benefit from pre-service VET investments. It is not unreasonable to expect that at least 50% of these 17,000 beneficiaries will come from relatively poor households. Women, in particular, have very low levels of literacy, basic education and training, and very little access to training opportunities. On the other hand, they represent a large share of workers in the informal sector, engaged in agro-processing, dressmaking, soapmaking, dyeing, commerce, and other trades. Through the Vocational Training Support Fund, the project would reach out and support the training of female workers in small and micro-enterprises, in both formal and informal sectors, and would provide women with greater opportunities to enhance their skills, productivity and earnings. To ensure this, project design calls for the appointment of a Womens' Training Specialist to the Training Fund, who would be responsable for initiating contacts among womens' groups, explaining the Fund, providing technical assistance to women interested in applying for Fund financing, and ensuring that Fund-financed training activities are adapted in content, location and cost to womens' needs. In summary, approximately one-half of project beneficiaries are expected to come from relatively poor households, with the rest coming from the lower-middle and middle classes. The project would make special efforts to see that women represent at least 40% of all in-service trainees, although specific quotas with respect to Fund financing for women would not be applied.

Methodology 500 apprentices, 300 master artisans and 200 apprentices' families were surveyed, covering a wide and representative range of professional trades. Results Sociological. An estimated 65,000 apprentices participate in informal sector vocational training, 45,000 in Bamako alone. This makes apprenticeship training the primary source of vocational training in Mali. 63% of artisans surveyed stated they employed apprentices, on average between 3-5. 60% of artisans never attended primary school, and only 20% stated they had ever participated in organized vocational training. Among apprentices, 68% declared to have attended primary school, and their- average age was 23 years old (90% were between 15-30). 80% of apprentices stated their intention was to set up their own business. Apprenticeship training is based on informal agreements between the artisan, the apprentice and his/her family. This social contract has the advantage of being simple and flexible, and is based on respect for the artisan's professional skills and seniority. On the other hand, apprentices have no objective means of '"raduating" and often end up as cheap labor for the master artisan for many years. 70% of apprentices surveyed stated they would be in favor of standardized apprenticeship certification procedures which would allow them to "graduate" and market themselves more easily. Pedagogv Instruction is a function of production, on-the-job learning by doing. Knowledge, skills and appropriate behavior are all passed on to the apprentice, through observation, imitation, and trial-and-error. While effective in transmitting practical skills, very little theoretical or written explanations are offered, in large part because most of the artisans are illiterate themselves. Furthermore, training depends entirely on the orders/contracts gained by the artisan, such that training may be very slow or limited in range. An average, training lasts from 3-5 years, but up to 10 years. Equipment is limited and generally of low quality, and artisans are typically traditional and resistant to new technologies. Well aware of apprenticeship's weaknesses, the vast majority of apprentices stated they would be interested in complementary, theoretical training, such as might be provided through a Vocational Training Fund.

Parents rarely pay the artisans for training services, although they do ensure medical care and food for their children. Apprentices may also earn a little extra money on the side through their own production or from client tips. The cost of establishing one's own business was estimated by apprentices at 100,000 CFAF, to be raised through personal savings and family assistance. According to 80% of artisans and 79% of apprentices, the informal sector and their particular trade offered additional employment opportunities. On the other hand, artisans expressed reservations about training too many young people in their trades, as this would create serious competition. Interpretation of Results The informal sector in Mali is changing rapidly. Artisans are organizing themselves into trade associations, the Government is encouraging an institutional and legal framework to promote informal sector development, the education system is unable to respond to the education, training and employment aspirations of young people and their families. New trades are appearing, and the link of certain ethnic groups to certain trades is disappearing. The fact that a majority of apprentices are literate and numerate, while most of their masters are not, means that their training is limited to purely practical, low-technology skills acquisition. An opportunity exists to provide complementary general skills and theoretical training to apprentices, which would build on the practical skills acquired through apprenticeship. A Vocational Training Fund could be an ideal vehicle to provide this training. The development of apprenticeship certification procedures and standards, which are accepted by artisans, employers and the Ministry of Education would be an important step in improving the marketability of apprentices and the respectability of the informal sector in general. Again, women face severe constraints. Women who work full-time, with families who expect them to simultaneously fulfill their "normal domestic responsibilities"(cooking, cleaning, child-rearing, etc.) simply do not have the time and energy to participate in most training activities. The distance to training centers is another factor, as many women do not want (or are forbidden) to travel alone, particularly in the evening. Finally, many husbands object to their wives' participation in training, for a variety of economic, social and cultural reasons. In terms of training neeeds, women identified technical skills/crafts training ('techniques artisanales') as most important, followed by training in management, accounting and marketing.  Annex 5.1 page 1 of2 Mali's Labor Code The adoption of Mali's revised labor code in September 1992 provides a more transparent framework for the operation of labor markets. The transparency has been achieved by introducing deadlines in enforcement procedures, which, in principal, would reduce the uncertainty facing employers regarding planned personnel action, and by establishing limits on damages that can be assessed for violations of the code. Prior uncertainty regarding the period of time require for approval of personnel actions by labor inspectors added to the expected cost of labor and reduced the incentive for employment creation. Steps have been taken in the revised labor code to reduce this uncertainty for employers, while retaining due process procedures for such actions as individual or collective dismissals. The code contains a number of features that enhance flexibility in the use of labor as a resource. Fixed-term contracts are legal as is part-time employment (Art. 133) in the face of economic downturns. Premiums paid for overtime are low by international standards (Art. 137). These features of the labor code enable employers to adjust labor costs in response to economic shocks and are favorable to employment growth. From an institutional perspective, the monopoly on job placement held by the state has been removed and the entry of private placement agencies is permitted (Art. 303). The competition this provides to the National Manpower Office (Office National de Ia Main- d'oeuvre et de l'Emploi) will improve labor intermediation. Against this favorable background of reforms, there remain a number of features in labor code that act as impediments to labor tiexibility and add to labor's cost. More important perhaps is the uncertainty that exists in the present environment regarding implementation of the revised labor code. Covering the impediments first, fixed-term contracts are available as an alternative to continuous or permanent contracts, but fixed-term contracts can only be renewed twice, after which the individual must be given a continuous contract (Art. 20). The latter brings with it the administrative cost of dismissals. Moreover, the fixed-term contract may be offered for a maximum of only two years in contrast to five years as found in many countries (Art.2 1). Fixed-term contracts along with reduced hours of work, flexible wages, profit-sharing, and sub-contracting have become instruments in industrialized countries for achieving labor flexibility; these instruments are not as developed as they could be under the revised code.. Other impediments remain which affect wage tiexibility. Rather than setting an economy- wide minimum wage, Mali sets minimum wages for different occupations (Art. 96). This adds to the risk of binding minimum wages, which discourages employment creation. In addition, seniority benefits are specified in the code (Art. 97), adding to wage rigidity. Although the increments mandated do no appear onerous, they are specified independent of productivity gains. Other dispositions intluencing labor cost and employment creation involve benefits. Annual leave of 30 days per year after a year of service, including non- working days, is high by international standards (Art. 151). Maternity leave for women of 14 weeks is generous and the number of times it can be used is not restricted (Art. 197), which discourages female employment given that Mali has one of the world's highest fertility rates.
 Annex 5.1 page 2 or 2 Mali's Labor Code (continued) At the same time as the cost of labor is raised for women, women are excluded from night work (Art. 186). Labor disputes for individuals and groups, while more transparent, are nevertheless encouraged by a labor tribunal process that is free to the plaintiff. No cost sharing or risk acceptance is required to discourage frivolous complaints (Art. 202). The effect of these measures and others is unclear in the present environment because many of the measures require that decrees and ministerial arretes be issued in order to fully implement the revised labor code. In fact, the Labor Code makes at least 27 references to such decrees and ministerial arretes. Most of these decrees have not yet been issued, in part due to opposition from the national unions, and thus, it is difficult to determine what impact the revised labor code is having on employment. In the final summary, the full effect of any labor code on economic activity and employment creation, either positive or negative, depends on its enforcement. In many developing countries, enforcement is weak, The uncertainty underlying this enforcement, however, remains a factor in the investment decisions of employers. Some measures of enforcement might be developed by an enterprise survey inquiring about such matters as the difficulty they face in getting permits to hire foreign labor to fill skill shortages, the number of labor inspections they have faced dluring the past 12 months, the outcome of these inspections and the time and resources required to settle claims, and the number of labor disputes that have been taken by employees to conciliation and arbitration. As part of the 1995-1997 Policy Framework Paper signed with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, the Government has agreed to review theimplementation of the revised labor code with the aim of identifying further areas of reform to allow more flexilibty in the functioning of the labor market. Following this, the legal framework of the revised Labor Cocde will be strengthened to ensure full application.

In addition, specific tasks such as review of progress reports, terms of reference, annual work plans. audits and procurement and disbursement actions, are estimated to require 12 staff-weeks during the first year of project execution and 8 staff-weeks of various specialists per subsequent year. The supervision of each component, including the review of procrement decisions and of progress reports, will be carried out by the task manager and procurement specialist under the responsibility of AF5PH. 1.2 Borrower's Contribution to Supervision (a) Semesterly Progress Reports would be submitted in April and October of each project year by the executing agencies, the Component Coordination Unit (CCU) and the Vocational Training Support Fund (VTSF). They would include a summary of implementation under each project component, financial statements on project expenditures, updated project implementation and records of contract advertising, bidding, and awards with indications of methods of procurement. The VTSF would also indicate the evolution of its financing of informal sector training sub- projects, (b) An implenmentation review workshop (annual review), convened by the CCU Coordinator in collaboration with the General Director of the VTSF, would be held in November of each project year. This would involve the participation of all project agencies and donors (the World Bank, the FAC, ILO, etc.). The workshop would be based on: (i) the semesterly progress reports mentioned above, (ii) preparation of an annual work program and estimated budget for the following project year; and (iii) the status of project performance indicators as listed in this annex; (c) Mid-Term Review. In addition, the CCU and VTSF would carry out not later than December 1998 a mid-term review of the progress made in implementing the project, from which lessons would be drawn and necessary corrective actions would be taken for the rest of the project duration. The review would cover all aspects of the project, with a special focus on, (i) the progress made by the VTSF in attracting women and other disadvantaged groups of beneficiaries to participate in Training Fund activities, (ii) the progress made by the VTSF in diversifying its sources of financing; (iii) the r evision of all pre-service VET curricula to be reinforced under the project and the introduction of the modular, competency based training approach in the classrooms,

Within six months of the Credit closing date, a project completion report prepared in accordance with terms of refrence satsifactory to IDA, would be transmitted to IDA.

doc.abstracts: The Vocational Education and Training (VET) Consolidation Project aims to contribute to economic growth and human resources development, targeting the skill requirements of relatively poor urban groups in the informal sector. Related objectives are to improve local capacity to allocate training resources as a function of labor market demand and to increase the involvement of the private sector in the management, provision and financing of VET. The project will finance three components: a) the consolidation of pre-service VET services, by upgrading facilities, revising curricula, improving teacher quality and increasing management capacity; b) the establishment of a Vocational Training Support Fund to develop demand-driven, employer-financed skills upgrading and apprenticeship training; and c) the establishment of an Employment and Training Observatory, to improve labor market information analysis and dissemination.
